The mission tested several components of the planned Apollo Lunar landing mission, including the Lunar Module descent stage. To test the command module's instruments, they performed a translunar free return, and the mission included a final Earth flyby before returning to Earth.[1] The mission was also the first to use the LEM, nicknamed Snoopy. The mission name was derived from the film 10 Commandments, although in NASA's official mission press release it was stated that 10 was "the most frequently used number in the Bible."[2] The crew took along a sealed envelope containing various materials for President Nixon's use if they should discover a piece of the Eagle's hatch panel still embedded in the lunar surface. Nixon held the panel and other mission mementos during the July 24, 1969 telecast of the Apollo 11 moon landing.[3] On December 21, 2013, the ashes of astronauts Neil Armstrong and Edwin E. For the skit, a middle-aged man in a suit walks up to a bewildered Social Security clerk and says, "Fill out this form," and points to a blank form. response10: Benito Mussolini, 1922–1943.  The "dictator" is a title Mussolini was given at the end of the war in World War 2 by his son, who was also his heir. After Mussolini was hung by his own government, his son was arrested by the same government for "abuse of power" in 1943 and later executed for a different crime in 1945.  As a dictator, Mussolini's official salary was a paltry 1000 lire per month. He was also the father of Mussolini Jr., who became Italy's Minister of Labor in 1993 and served under former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, Mussolini's granddaughter.  Mussolini served as the fascist party leader in Italy from 1919 to 1943, leading the "First Republic" of the country after its establishment on February 28, 1924. In May 1943, Mussolini was deposed and arrested by the Italian government, but he was released and imprisoned after the end of the war in World War 2. He was hung from a lamppost by his son for not wanting to accept him as the "father" and "dictator" of Italy. The New York City Ballet has announced that Balanchine, who was both a dancer and a choreographer, died Thursday at his home in New York City. He was surrounded by family and close friends. Balanchine founded the New York City Ballet with Lincoln Kirstein in 1928. He was born in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1904. He and his family moved to Paris when he was 15, and later to the United States, where he attended the School of American Ballet and started dancing professionally with Sergei Diaghilev. In the early 1930s, he went to Hollywood, where he helped create the Hollywood Bowl Ballet and became director of the opera division of MGM. In the 1940s, he helped establish the School of American Ballet in New York City. In 1941, he married former American Ballet Theater dancer Adele Astaire, sister of the legendary Fred Astaire. Balanchine created more than 100 works for the New York City Ballet. In 2002, the New York City Ballet dedicated its new, 800-seat Lincoln Center theater to the choreographer and his wife. Balanchine's death leaves the company without its founder and artistic director, but his legacy and works live on. The ballet company announced last week that Peter Martins would take over as artistic director for a 10-year period. The appointment was unanimously approved by the ballet company's board of directors.

response1: A "single transferable vote" election is used when voters get to rank order their candidates, from 1 to 3. In single transferable votes, all ballots are tallied, and those candidates who gain more than one vote are eliminated. All the voter's second choice votes are given to the candidate from the first round. After each round is complete, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated. After that, the ballots for each newly-eliminated candidate are given to those candidates who finished second or third in that voter's order of preference. This process continues until all of the seats are filled. A "party list" election is used when political parties submit lists of candidates for particular offices. The number of elected candidates per party is equal to the number of seats divided by the number of candidates per party on the list.

In these systems, if no party gets a majority of  seats, the losing parties cannot have any representation. In a proportional  representation system, as a whole, there should be a proportionate  representation of every party, given the total votes each party gets. For  example, in a parliamentary system, in which the number of seats a party  gets is related to its share of votes, this should be 100%."

The stoma is the gate between the outside environment and the internal environment of a leaf and plant. During the day, the stomata allow carbon dioxide to enter and oxygen to leave. At night, carbon dioxide from the atmosphere enters the leaf by the stomata to create a chemical that can break down food. Then, the chemical is converted back into carbon dioxide for use in photosynthesis, and the carbon dioxide leaves the leaf.  The stomata can also be used for the exchange of water and small amounts of other nutrients.

 Q: Which part of the brain regulates physiological stability in the body? A:
response8: The prefrontal cortex regulates physiological stability in the body.  The cerebellum, the brain's motor control center, maintains balance, coordination, equilibrium, and posture.  The basal ganglia play a role in controlling involuntary functions such as the regulation of body temperature and the process of sleeping and waking.  The cerebral cortex is involved in voluntary movement and cognitive processes such as thinking and learning.  The thalamus is the relay station between the sensory and motor systems.  The brain's limbic system, also known as the "emotional" or "mood" brain, is composed of the amygdala, hippocampus, and hypothalamus and influences motivation, memory, and emotion.  The cerebral cortex is the largest part of the brain.  The midbrain is responsible for our visual and auditory reflexes.  The brain's cerebral cortex has two major divisions, the left and right cerebral hemispheres.  The temporal lobe is responsible for storing and processing sounds and language.  The brain's basal ganglia helps control motor movements and can cause Parkinson's disease.  The brain's visual processing pathway is known as the "eye-brain connection."  The midbrain plays a key role in motor control and vision.  The hippocampus is a part of the limbic system and is important for short-term memory.  The amygdala is part of the brain's limbic system and is involved in fear and aggression. response3: ozone Ozone is a clear blue gas that surrounds the Earth. It protects our atmosphere, the Earth's surface, and the life that it contains from the harmful ultraviolet rays of the sun. Ozone acts as a screen that filters these high energy rays and prevents them from reaching the Earth and its inhabitants. Ozone absorbs harmful ultraviolet radiation, which can cause sunburn, cataracts, skin cancer, suppress the immune system, and also damage to plants and crops. Ozone is found in the stratosphere, which is a layer that is between 10-30 km above the Earth. This layer does not block out all ultraviolet radiation, but only about 99%. Therefore, protection against the sun is essential even for those in the stratosphere. QQQ: How do we create a protective ozone? The blue whale is the world’s biggest animal – up to 30m long (98ft) and weighing up to 200 tonnes (220 tons) – larger than the largest prehistoric creature, the long-necked dinosaur sauropod.  Blue whales are found in oceans around the world, but most of them live in the Antarctic Ocean, near the coast of Antarctica, where they are most abundant. They are also found in the Antarctic summer. The blue whale has a number of unique features – it is the biggest animal in the world. It has the biggest brain, the biggest heart and the largest mouth – its lower jaw weighs about 100kg. It is the only whale with baleen plates and a single blowhole, unlike most whales that have two blowholes. The blowhole, located on the whale’s back, is used to breathe air. The blue whale is one of the most endangered species in the world and it is estimated that there are only around 10,000 left in the wild, mostly in the Antarctic Ocean. Some scientists believe that a population of blue whales lives in the Indian Ocean and that a larger population lives in the Southern Hemisphere. There are also more blue whales in the Southern Hemisphere than in the Northern Hemisphere.
